content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Katherine Wright: I was born in Lansing, Michigan, and grew up in a small town in the East North Central region. My parents were never really together, and by the time I was 16, they were separated. My mom worked full-time as a receptionist, and she always made sure I had everything I needed, even though we were struggling financially. My dad didn't stay involved much, and he only finished high school. My mom, on the other hand, earned her bachelor's degree, and she always encouraged me to keep going with my education. I was a pretty quiet kid, but I had a strong work ethic. I worked part-time at a local bookstore while I was in high school, which helped me save up for college. I went to a state university, where I studied business, and I graduated with a bachelor's degree. I've been working full-time as a customer service manager for a small company ever since. I've never married, and I don't see myself getting married anytime soon. I'm pretty focused on my career and my independence. I'm a Protestant, and I've always been pretty religious, though I don't go to church as often as I used to. I'm proud to be an American citizen, and I've always believed in hard work and self-reliance, which is why I've always leaned toward conservative values and identify as a strong Republican.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Katherine Wright: There was definitely a crossroads in my life, and it happened right after I graduated from high school. I had the option to go to a local community college or take a job at a manufacturing plant that offered a steady paycheck. My mom was really worried about money, and she wanted me to start working right away to help out. But I remember sitting in my room one night, looking at my college applications, and thinking about my mom's sacrifices. She had gone back to school while working full-time, and she always told me that education was the key to a better life. I decided to take the harder path and go to college. It wasn't easy—I had to work part-time while studying, and there were times when I felt like giving up. But I kept pushing through, and that decision shaped who I am today. It taught me resilience, responsibility, and the value of hard work. I don't think I would be where I am now if I had chosen the other path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Katherine Wright: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it felt like it just happened in the moment. I remember feeling the weight of that decision, knowing that I was choosing a path that wasn't the easiest, but one that aligned with my values and my mom's sacrifices. I didn't just wake up one day and decide to go to college—I had been thinking about it for a long time, even as a kid. I saw how hard my mom worked to give me opportunities, and I didn't want to let that go to waste. So, I made a decision that day, even if it wasn't a dramatic moment with fireworks or anything. It was just me, sitting in my room, realizing that I had the chance to build a better future for myself, and I chose to take it.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Katherine Wright: Absolutely, I think a lot of people could have helped, but I didn't really reach out for support at the time. My mom was the one who pushed me the most, and I think she saw something in me that I didn't see in myself. I remember she sat me down one evening and just said, 'Katherine, you have a chance to do something more with your life than I ever could. Don't waste it.' That stuck with me. I also had a teacher in high school who noticed I was working hard and encouraged me to apply for scholarships. Without her, I might not have known where to start. But I think, at the end of the day, it was my own determination that got me through. I didn't want to rely on anyone else—I wanted to prove to myself that I could make it on my own.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Katherine Wright: I don't have a partner or children right now. My life is pretty focused on my job and my personal goals. I live alone in Lansing, in a small apartment I rent from a family friend. My mom still lives in the same town where I grew up, and we talk pretty often. She's retired now, but she's always been my biggest supporter. I visit her whenever I can, and we usually have long conversations about life, faith, and the future. I don't see myself getting married anytime soon—I think I'm too focused on my career and my independence. I like the freedom of being on my own, and I don't want to compromise my values or my ambitions for someone else. That said, I'm not closed off to the idea of a relationship. I just want it to be the right one, someone who shares my values and understands the importance of hard work and responsibility.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. It's interesting to look back at my life and see how my upbringing, my mom's influence, and my own determination shaped the person I am today. I never thought much about the crossroads I faced after high school until I was asked about it—it reminded me how important that decision was in defining my path. I also realized how much my mom and that teacher meant to me, even if I didn't always recognize it at the time. Talking about my current life, without a partner or children, made me appreciate how much I value my independence and my career. I'm proud of the choices I've made and the person I've become, even if I didn't always see it clearly back then.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Katherine Wright: My dad is still around, but we don't have a close relationship. He moved out when I was young and hasn't been very involved in my life since. I know he had his own struggles, and I don't hold a grudge, but I don't really see him as a part of my life anymore. My mom is the one who's always been there for me, and I think that's why I've always valued family so much, even if I'm not in a traditional family structure now. I also have an older sister who lives in Ohio. She's a nurse, and we don't talk as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's always nice to catch up. She's married with two kids, and while I admire her for building a family, I think I'm just not ready for that kind of commitment yet. I respect her choices, though, and I know she's always been proud of me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Katherine Wright: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends from college who I still keep in touch with. One of them, Sarah, works in marketing, and we used to meet up every few months for coffee or lunch. We bonded over our shared experiences of balancing school and work, and she was always the one who kept me grounded when I was feeling overwhelmed. I also have a couple of coworkers I consider friends—people I can rely on for support and advice. I don't have a large social circle, but the people I do know, I value deeply. I think my personality is just more introverted, and I prefer meaningful conversations over large gatherings. I enjoy reading, hiking, and volunteering at a local food pantry on weekends. It gives me a sense of purpose outside of work, and it reminds me of how lucky I am to have the opportunities I do. I don't think I'd ever been the type to seek out a lot of social interaction, but I do believe in giving back and helping others when I can.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Katherine Wright: I live in a quiet neighborhood on the east side of Lansing, not too far from where I grew up. It's a mix of older homes and newer apartments, and there's a real sense of community here. The streets are tree-lined, and there are a few local parks where I like to go for walks or hikes on the weekends. I rent a small two-bedroom apartment from a family friend, which is convenient and affordable. It's not much, but it's comfortable, and I've decorated it with a few things I've collected over the years—some books, a couple of plants, and a few pictures of my mom and me. I like the simplicity of it. I don't need a lot to be happy. The area is pretty safe, and there are a few local businesses nearby—like a small café where I grab coffee on my way to work, and a library I sometimes visit for quiet study time or just to read. I enjoy the slower pace of life here, and I think it's helped me stay focused on what's important. It's not the most exciting place in the world, but it's home, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Katherine Wright: I definitely feel safe in my neighborhood. It's not the kind of place where you have to worry about crime or strangers lurking around every corner. I've lived here for a few years now, and I've never had any issues. The people here are friendly, and there's a real sense of community. I know most of my neighbors by name, and they know me too. It's a quiet, peaceful place that allows me to focus on my work and my personal goals without the distractions or stress that come with living in a more chaotic environment. I think safety is something I take for granted, but I'm grateful for it. It gives me a sense of stability, which is important to me, especially considering my background. I've always valued security, both in my personal life and in the places I live, and I think this neighborhood provides that in a way that feels genuine and real.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Katherine Wright: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the sense of peace and stability I feel. I don't have to worry about loud noises at night or feeling unsafe walking home from work, which is something I never took for granted growing up. I remember when I was younger, we lived in a more run-down part of town, and there were times when I felt like I didn't have much control over my environment. Now, I feel like I do. That said, there are downsides too. The neighborhood isn't very diverse, and I sometimes feel like I'm in a bubble. There aren't a lot of cultural events or things to do outside of the usual chain stores and local parks. But honestly, I don't need much to be happy. I enjoy the quiet, the simplicity, and the fact that I can walk to most places without a car. It's not perfect, but it's exactly what I need right now. I think I've come to accept that not every place is going to be exciting or full of life, and that's okay. What matters is that I'm content and that I can focus on what's important—my work, my family, and my future.

Going through the interview questions about my family, relationships, and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made and the people who have supported me along the way. Talking about not having a partner or children reminded me of how much I value my independence and the freedom to focus on my career and personal goals. It also made me appreciate how much my mom has been a constant presence in my life, even when I didn't always realize it. Describing my current neighborhood and how I feel about living there brought back memories of my past and how far I've come. I've always valued stability and security, and it's comforting to know that I live in a place where I feel safe and at peace. While my neighborhood may not be the most exciting, it's exactly what I need right now—quiet, simple, and full of the things that matter most to me. I'm grateful for the life I've built and the people who have helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Katherine Wright: A typical week for me is pretty structured. I start my week on Monday with my usual routine—waking up early, having a quick breakfast, and heading to work. I work full-time as a customer service manager, so my days are pretty consistent. I usually get up around 6:30 a.m., and I like to have a cup of coffee while I read the news or a chapter of a book before heading out. My job keeps me busy, but I try to take short breaks throughout the day to clear my head. On most days, I have meetings or calls with clients, and I handle a lot of customer inquiries. I work from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., and I usually leave work around 5:30 p.m. after a quick walk to clear my mind. I come home, make dinner, and spend some time relaxing or catching up on my reading. On weekends, I like to volunteer at the local food pantry, which gives me a sense of purpose outside of work. I also enjoy going for hikes in the nearby parks or just taking a quiet walk around the neighborhood. I don't have a lot of social events on the weekends, but I do like to meet up with a few friends for coffee or a casual lunch. I think the predictability of my week helps me stay focused and grounded, especially with everything else going on in my life. It's not the most exciting schedule, but it works for me.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Katherine Wright: I work full-time as a customer service manager for a small company that provides administrative support to local businesses. My job is pretty demanding, but I enjoy the challenge of problem-solving and helping people. I work Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., though I often stay a little later if there's something I need to wrap up. I've been in this role for about three years now, and it's given me a lot of stability, which is something I really value. I started out in a different position, but I worked my way up through dedication and hard work. I like that my job allows me to be independent and make decisions on my own, which is something that's always been important to me. It's not a high-paying job, but it's enough to cover my expenses and give me a little extra to save or spend on things I enjoy, like books or a nice meal out once in a while. I think I've found a good balance between work and my personal life, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Katherine Wright: Outside of work and my volunteer time, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends, because I find that consistency helps me feel more in control of my life. I also make it a point to read every night before bed—usually a non-fiction book or something related to personal development. It's a small habit, but it helps me reflect on my goals and keep my mind sharp. I also try to exercise a few times a week, mostly walking or doing some light yoga at home. It's not much, but it helps me manage stress and stay focused. I think these little routines are what keep me balanced, especially with the demands of work and everything else. I don't have a lot of time for extravagance, but I do believe in taking care of myself in the ways that matter most.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Katherine Wright: Actually, there have been a few small changes lately. I started taking a few online courses in my spare time—mostly business-related topics, like leadership and project management. I want to keep growing in my career, and I think these courses will help me move up in my company. It's been a bit of a shift in my routine, but I've been enjoying the challenge. I also started going to bed a little earlier, which has helped me feel more rested and focused during the day. It's funny how little adjustments can make a big difference in how you feel overall. I think I'm just trying to stay proactive about my future, you know? I don't want to stop growing, even if I'm not in a traditional path like some of my friends. I'm proud of where I am, but I also know there's more I can do if I keep pushing forward.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Katherine Wright: I don't have children, so I don't have a typical weekday routine for them. But I can imagine what it might be like, based on what my sister told me about her kids. From what I understand, their days start early with school, followed by after-school activities like sports or music lessons. My sister said it's a busy schedule, but she loves seeing her kids grow and learn new things. I admire her for that—raising a family while balancing work and personal life must be challenging. I think I'm just not ready for that kind of responsibility yet, but I respect those who are. It's a big commitment, and I want to make sure I'm fully prepared if the time ever comes.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my daily life and routines have shaped who I am today. Talking about my neighborhood reminded me of how important stability and safety are to me, especially after growing up in a less secure environment. It's comforting to know that I live in a place where I feel at peace and can focus on my goals without distractions. Reflecting on my job and work schedule also made me appreciate how much I've built my life around consistency and responsibility. I've always valued hard work, and seeing how my routine has helped me stay grounded and focused reinforces that belief. The discussion about my personal routines, like reading and exercising, reminded me of the small things that keep me balanced and in control of my life. I think these routines are what help me stay resilient, especially when things get overwhelming. Overall, going through these questions made me realize how much I've come to value structure, independence, and the quiet simplicity of my life right now.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Katherine Wright: In terms of my health, I would say I'm pretty average. I don't have any major medical conditions, but I do struggle with occasional stress-related issues, like mild anxiety when work gets overwhelming. I've learned to manage it through routine, exercise, and reading—things that help me stay grounded. I try to eat healthy, mostly home-cooked meals, and I limit processed foods as much as I can. I know I could be better about it, but with my schedule and budget, it's not always easy. I also make sure to see my doctor regularly for check-ups, just to be safe. I think staying proactive about my health is important, especially since I don't have a partner or family to look out for me the way my mom does. I'm grateful that I haven't had any serious health problems, and I try to take care of myself the best I can with what I have.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Katherine Wright: Staying healthy is something I have to be intentional about, especially with my schedule and budget. On the easier side, I find that having a routine helps a lot. Knowing that I need to get up at the same time every day, eat meals at regular intervals, and take time for exercise—even if it's just a walk—makes it easier to stay on track. I also appreciate that I live in a neighborhood where I can walk or bike to most places, which keeps me active without needing to spend extra money on a gym membership. On the harder side, it's the stress of work and the financial constraints that make it tough. Sometimes, I feel like I don't have the time or resources to eat the healthiest meals or take the best care of myself. I know I could do better, but I'm learning to be more patient with myself and celebrate the small victories, like choosing a salad over fast food or taking a few minutes to breathe deeply when things get overwhelming. I think the key is balance, and I'm trying to find that in my own way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Katherine Wright: Actually, there hasn't been anything major in the past two years related to my health. I've been pretty consistent with my routine, and I haven't had any serious medical issues. The only thing I've noticed is that my back has been a little sore lately, probably from sitting at my desk for long hours at work. I've started taking more breaks and stretching during the day, which has helped a bit. I also had a minor flare-up of my anxiety a few months ago, right after a busy project at work. It wasn't anything too severe, but it reminded me how important it is to take care of my mental health too. I've been trying to be more mindful, and I've even started journaling a little to help process my thoughts. I think it's all part of the journey—learning how to balance work, life, and health in a way that works for me.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Katherine Wright: Honestly, I haven't had any health issues that have really impacted my ability to work or manage my life. My back soreness and occasional anxiety are things I can manage with small adjustments—like taking more breaks, stretching, or just taking a few deep breaths when things get overwhelming. I know that if something more serious were to happen, it would be harder, but right now, I feel pretty in control of my health. I think that's partly because I've always been pretty independent and used to taking care of myself. I don't rely on anyone else for support, so I make sure I do what I need to stay healthy. I also know that if something were to change, I have my mom to lean on, and that gives me a sense of security. I don't want to dwell on what-ifs, though. I'm focused on the present, and I'm doing the best I can with what I have.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Katherine Wright: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of things—mostly steady, but with a few moments of reflection and growth. Life hasn't been too dramatic, but I think I've been more aware of how much I've come to value the little things. I've been really focused on my work, and I've taken on a few new responsibilities at the company, which has been both challenging and rewarding. It's given me a sense of accomplishment, and I think it's helped me feel more confident in my abilities. On a personal level, I've been trying to be more intentional with my time, whether it's reading more, volunteering, or just taking a walk in the park. I've also been thinking a lot about my future—where I want to be in five or ten years, and what that might look like. I don't know if I'm any closer to figuring it out, but I feel like I'm moving forward, even if it's not always in a straight line. I've also been more in touch with my mom, which has been comforting. She's always been my rock, and I think talking to her more has helped me stay grounded. I don't know if I'd say I'm happier than I was before, but I feel more at peace with where I am and the choices I've made. I think that's the most important thing—knowing that I'm living a life that's true to who I am, even if it's not what other people might expect.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me think a lot about how my daily routines and health are connected to the person I've become. Reflecting on the small changes I've made, like taking online courses and going to bed earlier, reminded me that growth doesn't always have to be dramatic—it can be subtle, like adjusting your habits a little at a time. It also made me realize how much I value consistency and structure, especially when it comes to managing my health. I've always believed in hard work and self-reliance, and that mindset has carried over into how I take care of myself, even when it's not always easy. I'm learning that it's okay to not be perfect, and that small victories, like choosing a healthy meal or taking a walk, are just as important as the bigger ones. I'm grateful for the routines that keep me grounded and for the awareness that I'm constantly growing, even if I don't always see it right away.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Katherine Wright: I think I've always had moments of anxiety, especially when things felt uncertain or when work was really overwhelming. But I wouldn't say I've struggled with depression or anything like that. I've learned to manage it through routine, prayer, and talking to my mom when I need to. I know some people might see my life as pretty simple or even lonely, but I don't feel that way. I have my independence, my job, and my faith, and I think those things give me a sense of purpose. I've had days where I felt down or unsure about my future, but I've always found a way to push through. I think part of it is my personality—I'm not someone who likes to dwell on negative thoughts for too long. I focus on what I can control, and that usually helps me stay grounded. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm trying to be honest with myself and take care of my mental health the best I can.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Katherine Wright: For my family, things have been pretty steady too. My mom is doing well, though she's starting to feel the effects of aging more these days. She's always been independent, but I can tell she's starting to rely on me a little more for things like errands or helping her with the computer. It's not a burden, though—it just feels natural to take care of her in the way she took care of me. My sister is busy with her family, but she checks in on us from time to time. I think she's proud of me, even if she doesn't always say it out loud. I know she worries about me not having a partner or kids, but I don't feel like I'm missing out. I have my own life, my own goals, and I'm content with that. I think my family has always been about support and love, even if we don't always express it in the same way. I'm grateful for them, and I know they're always there for me, even if we don't see each other as often as I'd like.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Katherine Wright: I think religion has always been a part of my life, even if I don't go to church as often as I used to. My mom was very involved in our church growing up, and I remember sitting in those Sunday services, listening to the sermons, and feeling a sense of peace that I couldn't explain. It wasn't just about the rules or the traditions—it was about the community, the sense of belonging, and the belief that there was something bigger than myself. Over time, as I got older and started focusing more on my education and career, I didn't attend church as much, but I still hold onto my faith. I pray sometimes, especially when things feel overwhelming, and I find comfort in knowing that I'm not alone. I don't claim to be perfect, and I don't always understand why things happen the way they do, but I believe in God's plan and in the strength that comes from faith. It's not something I talk about a lot, but it's a foundation that's always been there for me, especially during difficult times. I think that's why I've always leaned toward conservative values and Republican politics—it all ties back to that sense of structure, responsibility, and belief in something greater than myself.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Katherine Wright: I don't use social media very often, honestly. I know a lot of people my age are always on Facebook or Instagram, but I've never really felt the need to be part of that world. I think it's more about staying connected with my family and friends, and I prefer talking to them in person or over the phone rather than scrolling through posts or trying to keep up with everyone's lives online. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with my mom and my sister, but I don't post much or interact with other people's content. I find it a bit overwhelming, to be honest. There's so much noise and comparison, and I don't want to get caught up in that. I'd rather focus on my own life, my goals, and the people who matter most. I do follow a few pages related to personal development or faith, just to get some inspiration or reminders about staying grounded. But overall, I think I'm more of a private person when it comes to these platforms. I don't mind being offline, and I think it helps me stay focused on what's really important.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Katherine Wright: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support during tough times. I've always found that the people I care about are the ones who matter most, and I prefer reaching out to them directly rather than posting something online and waiting for a response. I know some people find comfort in seeing messages of encouragement from strangers or friends, but I think I'm more of an in-person person. When I've had a hard time, my mom has always been there for me—whether it was a phone call, a visit, or just someone to listen. I don't think I've ever felt the need to broadcast my struggles to the world. I've always believed in handling things privately and relying on the people I know and trust. That said, I can see how it might help others, especially if they don't have a strong support system. I just know that for me, it's not something I need.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and emotional well-being are deeply tied to the structure and independence I've built in my life. Talking about my recent health, like the back soreness and occasional anxiety, reminded me that even small challenges can be managed with consistency and self-awareness. It also made me think about how I've always relied on my own routines—like waking up at the same time, reading before bed, and taking short walks—to stay grounded. I realized that while I don't always see myself as someone who struggles with mental health, I do have moments where I feel overwhelmed, and that's okay. What matters is that I've learned how to handle those feelings without relying on others, which is something I've always valued. Reflecting on my past year, I felt a sense of growth—not necessarily in dramatic changes, but in the quiet confidence that comes from knowing I'm living a life that's true to who I am. I'm not perfect, and I don't always have all the answers, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to celebrate the small victories that keep me moving forward.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Katherine Wright: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have been pretty steady, though I've been more aware of how I handle it. I used to push through everything without really stopping to think about how I was feeling, but now I make a conscious effort to check in with myself. When things get overwhelming at work, I take short breaks to walk around the block or just sit outside for a few minutes and breathe. I've also started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and clear my mind. I think it's important to acknowledge when I'm feeling stressed instead of ignoring it, and I've found that small, intentional actions—like reading before bed or taking a few deep breaths—make a big difference. I don't know if I'm any better at managing stress than I was before, but I feel more in control of it now. I guess that's the goal, right? To not let it take over, but to find ways to keep moving forward even when things feel heavy.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Katherine Wright: My biggest expenses last month were my rent, which is pretty affordable since I'm renting from a family friend, and my groceries. I also have a car payment, though I drive an older model that I bought used a few years back—it's reliable, but not the most fuel-efficient. I try to budget carefully, setting aside money for utilities, phone bills, and a small amount for savings. I don't spend much on entertainment or shopping, mostly because I don't have a lot of extra income. I do splurge a little on books or a nice meal out once in a while, but for the most part, I stick to what's necessary. I've always been pretty frugal, and I think it's something I learned growing up. My mom always made sure we had what we needed, but there was never much extra. I've carried that mindset into my adult life, and I don't mind it. It gives me peace of mind knowing that I'm not living paycheck to paycheck, and I can save a little for the future. I know it's not glamorous, but it works for me.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Katherine Wright: My household spending last month was pretty much in line with what I usually spend. I'd say it came out to around $1,800, give or take a little. Most of that goes to rent, which is about $700 a month, and groceries, which I try to keep around $400. The rest covers utilities, my phone bill, and a small amount for savings. I don't usually have a lot of extra expenses, but I do set aside a little money each month for things like books or a nice dinner out—maybe $100 or so. I've always been pretty careful with my money, and I think it's something I learned from growing up in a household where we had to be mindful of every dollar. I don't have a lot, but I don't need much to be happy. It's not about living extravagantly—it's about having what I need and being able to plan for the future. I know I could be making more money, but I'm content with where I am right now. It's not about the amount, but about the stability and the freedom that comes with it.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Katherine Wright: We rent our home, actually. I live in a small two-bedroom apartment on the east side of Lansing, which I rent from a family friend. It's not much, but it's comfortable and affordable. Rent is about $700 a month, which is manageable given my income. I've always preferred renting over buying because I like the flexibility it offers. I don't see myself settling down in one place for too long, and I want to keep my options open. Plus, with my current job and lifestyle, I don't think I need a lot of space. I've learned to be content with what I have, and I think that's something I've carried with me since I was younger. My mom always said that home isn't about the size of the house, but about the people in it—and I think that's true. Even though I live alone now, I feel like I have a home because it's where I can be myself, focus on my goals, and take care of my health. It's simple, but it works for me.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Katherine Wright: Over the past year, my bills have stayed pretty consistent, which is something I appreciate. Rent is always the same, and my utilities don't fluctuate much because I'm careful with energy use—turning off lights when I leave a room, using the heater only when necessary, and keeping my water usage low. Groceries do change a bit with the seasons, though. In the winter, I tend to spend a little more on fresh produce and heating supplies, but I make up for it in the summer when things are cheaper. I also have a few fixed costs like my phone bill and car payment, which don't really change. The only time I notice a bigger shift is around the holidays, when I might spend a little more on a gift for my mom or a small treat for myself. But I always try to keep it under control, because I know that stability is what keeps me grounded. I don't like surprises, especially when it comes to money, so I've learned to plan ahead and stick to a budget. It's not always easy, but it's something I've come to rely on, especially after growing up in a household where every dollar counted.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how my family and my approach to emotional support are deeply connected to the values I've held throughout my life. Talking about my mom and how she's been a constant presence in my life reminded me of how much I've come to rely on the people I trust most, rather than seeking support from strangers or online communities. I've always believed in handling things privately and relying on the people I know, and that's something I've carried with me even as I've grown older. Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Katherine Wright: I do have a savings account, and I try to save a little bit every month, even if it's just a small amount. I think it's important to have a financial cushion, especially since I don't have a partner or family to fall back on in the way some people do. I set aside about $100 a month, which doesn't seem like much, but over time, it adds up. I've always believed in being prepared for the unexpected, and I know that life can change in an instant. My mom always taught me that saving is a form of independence, and I've carried that lesson with me. I don't save for anything extravagant—I just want to make sure I can handle emergencies, like a car repair or a medical bill, without having to rely on credit or loans. It's not about being rich, but about having a sense of security. I know I could save more, but I also know that I have to balance it with my current needs and goals. For now, I'm content with what I have, and I'm proud that I've built that habit over the years.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Katherine Wright: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing rather than a big purchase like a home. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon—I like the flexibility that renting gives me, and I don't want to get tied down by a mortgage or property taxes. What matters to me is having that safety net in case something unexpected happens, like a medical bill or a car repair. I know I could save more, but I also know I have to balance that with my current needs. I don't want to live paycheck to paycheck, but I also don't want to sacrifice the little things that make me happy, like buying a book or having a nice meal out once in a while. It's about finding that balance, and I think I've done a pretty good job of it so far. I'm not saving for anything extravagant—I'm just trying to make sure I'm prepared for whatever life throws my way.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Katherine Wright: My occupation is as a customer service manager for a small company that provides administrative support to local businesses. In this role, my main responsibilities include overseeing a team of customer service representatives, handling client inquiries, resolving issues, and ensuring that our clients receive the support they need in a timely and efficient manner. I also spend a lot of time analyzing customer feedback and working with other departments to improve our processes and services. The most important part of my job is problem-solving—whether it's helping a client with a billing issue or figuring out how to streamline our internal operations. I enjoy the challenge of it, and I take pride in knowing that my work helps keep businesses running smoothly. It's not always glamorous, but I find satisfaction in the structure and the sense of accomplishment that comes with doing a good job. I think this job fits well with who I am—someone who values responsibility, independence, and the ability to make a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Katherine Wright: I usually work around 40 hours a week, Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Some weeks are a bit longer if there are deadlines or projects that need extra attention, but I try to keep it consistent. I've always valued structure, and having a regular schedule helps me stay focused and productive. I don't mind the hours—I think they're fair, and they give me the stability I need to take care of my responsibilities. I also appreciate that my job allows me to be independent and make decisions on my own, which is something that's always been important to me. I know it's not the most exciting job in the world, but it's one that I can rely on, and that's something I really value.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Katherine Wright: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on one role at a time, which I think has helped me stay dedicated and avoid burnout. When I was in college, I worked part-time at a local bookstore, but that was just to help with expenses and didn't interfere with my studies. After I graduated, I started my current job as a customer service manager, and I've been in that role for the past three years. I don't see the need to take on extra work—I believe in doing one thing well rather than spreading myself too thin. Plus, with my current schedule, I have enough time to take care of my responsibilities, volunteer, and maintain my routines. I think it's about balance, and for me, that balance is achieved by focusing on what I have rather than trying to do more than I can handle.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Katherine Wright: My household income last month was around $2,400. I've always been pretty careful with my money, and I think it's something I learned growing up. My mom always made sure we had what we needed, but there was never much extra. Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Katherine Wright: I've been at my current job for about three years now, and I've really come to appreciate the stability it offers. The company is small, which means I have a lot of responsibility and autonomy in my role, and I enjoy that. As for benefits, we have health insurance, which covers me and my mom, and that's something I'm really grateful for. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which I try to use wisely. I don't take a lot of time off, but it's good to know it's there if I need it. The company also offers a small retirement plan, which I contribute to every month, even if it's just a little. I think it's important to plan for the future, even if I don't have a lot to spare. Overall, the benefits are modest, but they're enough to give me a sense of security, which is something I've always valued. I don't have a lot, but I'm content with what I have, and I know that my job gives me the freedom and independence I need to live the life I want.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Katherine Wright: My relationships at work are pretty straightforward—professional, respectful, and built on mutual respect. I have a good relationship with my manager, who I consider more of a mentor than just a boss. She's been with the company for a while and has always been supportive of my growth. She trusts me to handle responsibilities on my own, which I really appreciate. I think that's why I've been able to move up in the company over the years. As for my coworkers, we get along well. We're all pretty focused on our tasks, but there's a sense of camaraderie when we take breaks or have lunch together. I don't have any close friends at work, but I don't need that kind of connection to feel comfortable. I value the structure and independence my job offers, and I think that's something my coworkers respect too. I don't really see myself as someone who needs a lot of social interaction at work—just enough to get the job done and maintain a good working relationship. I think that's why I've always fit in here, even if I'm not the most outgoing person.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Katherine Wright: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which is something I really appreciate. I start every Monday at 8:30 a.m. and finish at 5 p.m., with only minor variations when there's a big project or deadline coming up. I like the structure it gives me—it helps me plan my days, know when I can take breaks, and balance my personal life with my responsibilities. I don't have a lot of flexibility with my hours, which is fine with me. I've always valued consistency, and I think that's why I've always done well in roles like this. I don't mind the routine; in fact, I think it's what keeps me grounded. I know some people prefer more flexible hours or the ability to work remotely, but for me, showing up on time and having a clear schedule is what makes me feel in control of my life. It's not about being rigid—it's about knowing exactly what to expect, and that gives me peace of mind.

Katherine Wright: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation. Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Katherine Wright: Yes, my mom worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up—actually, she worked full-time throughout most of my childhood and teenage years. She was a receptionist at a local clinic, and she always made sure we had what we needed, even though we weren't well off. I remember her working long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted, but she never complained. She always said that education was the key to a better life, and she made sure I understood that from a young age. I think that's why I've always valued hard work and self-reliance so much. My dad didn't work as consistently, and he wasn't really involved in our daily lives, but my mom was the one who shaped my work ethic and my belief in the importance of earning your own way. She never asked for much, but she always gave me the tools I needed to build a better future for myself.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Katherine Wright: My mom worked as a receptionist at a local clinic, and her job was pretty demanding. She was the first person you saw when you walked in the door, and she handled everything from scheduling appointments to answering phones and managing the front desk. She had to be organized, polite, and always ready to help people, whether they were in a hurry or had a complicated issue. I remember seeing her work long hours, sometimes coming home late, but she always made sure to have dinner ready and to check in on me before going to bed. Her most important duties were making sure patients felt welcome and that the clinic ran smoothly. She took pride in her work, even though it wasn't a high-paying job, and she always said that doing a good job was more important than the money. I think that's why I've always valued responsibility and hard work so much—it all started with her example.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Katherine Wright: My mom worked at a small, family-owned clinic in our town. It wasn't a big hospital or anything like that—it was more of a general practice, where doctors saw patients for regular check-ups, minor illnesses, and prescriptions. The clinic was run by a doctor and his wife, and my mom was one of the few employees there. She was responsible for everything from scheduling appointments to managing the front desk, handling billing, and even sometimes helping out with basic medical tasks like taking temperatures or preparing rooms for patients. It wasn't the most glamorous job, but she took pride in it. She always said that the clinic was a place where people came for help, and she wanted to make sure they felt welcome and taken care of. I remember seeing her work long hours, sometimes staying late to make sure everything was in order before she went home. Even though the pay wasn't great, she never complained. She always said that the most important thing was doing a good job, and I think that's why I've always valued responsibility and hard work so much. Her example taught me that even the smallest jobs can make a big difference in people's lives, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Katherine Wright: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still in a place where I feel grounded, stable, and in control of my life. I don't know if I'll be in the same job or even the same city, but I hope I'm still working something that gives me a sense of purpose and responsibility. I'd like to have a little more financial security, maybe a bit more saved up, and I hope I'm still living in a neighborhood that feels safe and familiar. I also hope I'm still close to my mom, even if we don't see each other as often as I'd like. I don't know if I'll ever have a partner or children, and honestly, I'm okay with that. What matters to me is that I'm living a life that's true to who I am—someone who values independence, hard work, and the quiet simplicity of a well-structured day. I hope I'm still reading, still volunteering, and still growing in my career, even if it's not in the most dramatic way. I think the most important thing is that I'm content with where I am, and that I'm still moving forward, one step at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Katherine Wright: What I value the most in my life is the sense of independence and self-reliance that I've built over the years. I don't need a lot to be happy, but I do need to feel like I'm in control of my own path. I value the stability of having a job that allows me to support myself, the freedom to make my own decisions without relying on others, and the peace of mind that comes from knowing I've worked hard for what I have. I also value the relationships I've built—especially with my mom, who has always been my biggest supporter. I think what I value most is the quiet confidence that comes from knowing I've made the right choices for myself, even if they weren't the easiest ones. I don't need excitement or extravagance; I just need to feel grounded, responsible, and true to who I am.
